@oldandrewuk I don't believe assault should be thought of as inevitable. That would be a red flag for me and would suggest that behaviour is commonplace and/or excusable.

@oldandrewuk In a previous school I was punched by an 8 year old. Nothing was done. I was just to accept it because this boy was on the SEND register. Attitude was 'He must have been provoked'. I'd asked him to join the line, as I remember.

@ashhleigh16 Disgusting isn't it? Awful service @BensonsForBeds. I'll never recommend them to anyone. I hope I'll be compensated in some way for the constant push back of delivery date. My little boys have had to sleep on mattresses on the floor for weeks now.

@mcjinner 'This is Twitter' isn't an excuse for teachers to quote tweet or screen shot other people's classrooms just to criticise them. Entitled to opinions, yes. But there's a difference between commenting on a post & inviting others to join criticism by quote tweeting or screenshotting.

@MrTeach33 I still think quote tweeting or screen shotting other people's classrooms just to comment negatively on them is underhanded. There's nothing genuine about it other than to invite other people to join in the criticism.

@Lawsonpeak1 It's a bit of a smack in the face for a teacher to have others teachers rubbishing their classrooms/displays. Or seeing pictures of their classrooms shared by others without their knowledge. It's underhanded & using the excuse that it should be expected doesn't  fly with me.

@vouzidhmesloub @MissS_music Oh I don't doubt for a minute that some teachers feel the pressure. Hopefully there's enough teachers reassuring them that they don't need to follow what others are doing.
@vouzidhmesloub @MissS_music I'd say posting pictures of other people's classrooms or quotes tweeting them with comments that are not positive is uncalled for.

@MissGBurn Neither. I tend to pick out words that are relevant to what we're writing & put those on the word wall during vocabulary collection. Then the words are changed with each piece. This ensures I get a spread, but also avoids shoe horning the words into writing. Just a few each time.

@Loubedford1 I overhauled D&T in our school. We have the Projects on a Page planning and then I created bespoke projects from the topics they suggest. We do D&T once a term for a week where we block the afternoons.

@MichaelT1979 When I trained I did KS2/3 because I was told there were middle schools which gave scope for working across those key stages. Turned out they weren't as widespread as I was led to believe, which is a shame because I'd have loved to work in one.

@MrWithersAHT Pink and green highlighting of WALTs. I remember the scandal when some teachers used orange because to show a child had almost got it and this led to a lengthy staff meeting debate. So much wasted time!
@MrWithersAHT Individual target sheets for each child in reading, writing & Maths. Two stars and a wish for every piece of work. Detailed weekly plans.

@UnofficialOA Yes because all we do is stand at the front and deliver content to children who are all the same remember? We don't have to worry about such things as differing needs, SEND, behaviour, pastoral support, assessment etc. Our job is something anyone can do, clearly. üòÖ
@CmtDbutterfly Oh and RE 1hr & Humanities 1hr. As you can see this doesn't all fit so I have to alternate some.

@CmtDbutterfly We do:
English - 4 hours
Reading - 5x 45mins 
Maths- 5hrs
PE - 1hr 45mins
Science - 1hr 30mins
Art - 1hr (longer for some lessons if needed - e.g. using clay)
Music - 30mins
Computing - 30mins
PSHE - 30mins
D&T is blocked 3x a year
French - 1hr as we have a specialist

@NicolaMizon1 @MissL_Y6 @_MissieBee @MrsG_Year6 @JosephOak35 @mr_spayne For fiction we use The Arrival, Darwin's Dragons, Rooftoppers, Letters From The Lighthouse, The Harmonica & Rose Blanche. I think that's it. üòÖ

@krissyabc @rossp2112 This is another great point. Its not time That's needed - it's quality CPD so the subject can be taught well. If teachers feel more confident teaching a subject, that subject is less likely to be dropped off timetables.

@smithsmm @CensoredHead @MichaelT1979 RE is a challenging subject to teach and of all the subjects it's the one I've had little to no CPD in over 15 years of teaching. Most CPD tends to be around core subjects and PE in my experience.

@CensoredHead @MichaelT1979 MFL yes. The mistake made with D&T sometimes is the tendency to do junk modelling and making things without a clear purpose & user. The thing with any subject is that with prominence & CPD they can be taught well. We just have so many subjects & too much content in core subjects.

@bpootle3 @Emma_Turner75 We have 30mins Music, 30 mins PSHE, about 40 mins Computing, 1 hour Hist/Geography, 1hr/or 45mins Art, 1hr French (because we have a specialist teacher), 1hr 45mins PE, 1hr RE. 1 1/2 hrs Science. D&T is blocked.
@bpootle3 We can't give an hour to all of them though and that's the issue. Blocking time is helpful but even then other subjects have to be pushed aside.

@Smitche94700151 Consolidation is something very difficult to do in primary in subjects with many objectives to cover. Teaching a wide range of subjects is important but I wish the DfE would listen & cut the content down. Then we can do less but better. Really embed knowledge and skills.
@bpootle3 I'm not sure an hour of Music is feasible. Yes the profile needs to be raised so it is taught regularly, but I don't like the idea of it being given given hour. Half an hour, yes.

@MrKingPrimary D&T can be taught very well. We're raised the profile of D&T in our school this year and the children have loved it. Personally, I'd vote MFL. And I say this as someone who loves languages.

@Jonesy_K8 Subjects already have medium term planning in place so we simply follow them. I don't need to write weekly plans. Subjects like Maths & English that are adapted more than other subjects are still not planned weekly. Our PowerPoints & resources show what we're doing.

The more I see teachers talking about marking & planning the more grateful I am to work where I do. We don't have to do planning so my time is spent simply resourcing lessons. We don't have to write comments in books as we do whole class feedback. Saves a lot of time. #edutwitter

@AlleyMohindra @dix_a @EducEndowFoundn @MichaelT1979 @MaryMyatt This could be a transition problem between schools. If research suggests homework has little impact in primary, it makes no sense just to set it in Y6 to prepare them for Y7. What needs to happen is Y7 taking this research into account & adapting accordingly.
@MissTKS2 @dix_a @EducEndowFoundn @MichaelT1979 @MaryMyatt Oh that's awful!

@MissTKS2 @dix_a @EducEndowFoundn @MichaelT1979 @MaryMyatt I'd say on average 2/3 of my class completed it & I was reluctant to chase missing pieces. Often the missing pieces are from those who have limited support at home so why make them feel worse by highlighting the fact they haven't done work that others had support & time to do?

@MichaelT1979 @ianaddison @dix_a @EducEndowFoundn @MaryMyatt Yes, I've just said similar in response to someone else. Homework can be viewed as a window into the classroom. It could be argued that parent workshops or curriculum evenings would be better, but this also creates workload.

@dix_a @MaryMyatt @EducEndowFoundn @MichaelT1979 Some parents want homework because they think it boosts attainment & gives them a window into what their children are learning. Others have no time to support their children with it or find that homework plus reading & spelling etc is too much.

@ianaddison @dix_a @EducEndowFoundn @MichaelT1979 @MaryMyatt I think in some cases homework is more for parents. When it's not set, some aren't happy about it. But, this is possibly because they think it has a huge impact on attainment & that if their child doesn't get it, like X school down the road, then their child will fall behind.

@dix_a @EducEndowFoundn @MichaelT1979 @MaryMyatt Personally, I wish it wasn't set. I would rather the children read regularly, and learn their times tables than do weekly homework which I don't have time to really refer to. Finding or often creating tasks that I can put on our online platform just adds to workload.

@MrsBdoesHistory @Nazmameah1 4) As your tweets are seen more, you're open to having your tweets retweeted by anyone. This can leave you open to abuse depending on what you've tweeted. You also find people think you have better things to say/share because of your follower count & it's not always the case.

@MrsBdoesHistory @Nazmameah1 3) I'd say follower numbers doesn't matter. There are people with lower follower numbers with great things to say/share. What they don't have is a presence and that takes time. There are downsides to having more followers that should be noted, in my experience at least...

@MrsBdoesHistory @Nazmameah1 2) Interacting with more tweets gets you seen more. Use the #edutwitter hashtag on your own tweets. Using a gif or image with your tweet makes it stand out on a feed more. Mentioning a person in a tweet with their handle gets your tweet seen by that person...

@MrsBdoesHistory @Nazmameah1 1) It takes time to build followers & quite often it happens very naturally if you interact with tweets regularly. A lot of people with high follower numbers are on Twitter a lot, posting a lot, sharing ideas/resources etc. Some tips, if it will help...

@Mr_AlmondED Freedom to break the mould is also important. For example, our head isn't fussed if we block out time when needed. For example, sewing in D&T might be done all morning, rather than in lesson than an hour once a week.

@smithsmm @LTeacher123 @mflpickandmicks That's a great idea! We used to have a French specialist do something similar. She would teach one week, with the teacher observing and then we would do the following week - building on what she had delivered. Sadly budgets are so tight.

@nylesojj @_MissieBee @trialnerrorkt @teacher_mr_r @one_to_read @TeachRepeat Not fully. We do a book talk session a week.
@PieCorbett @FranRosevere @trialnerrorkt @teacher_mr_r @one_to_read @TeachRepeat This is what we do and it works well for us.

@PieCorbett @trialnerrorkt @teacher_mr_r @one_to_read @TeachRepeat I think belief was that guided reading meant a teacher had to be stuck with their group for the whole lesson while the other children did filler activities. There's no reason why shared reading can't take place first & then teachers focus on a group for the rest of the lesson.

@Mr_AlmondED @trialnerrorkt @teacher_mr_r @one_to_read @TeachRepeat Also, let's face it, planning activities for each group was a pain & some activities lacked purpose. E.g. I had teachers giving spelling practice tasks! Whole class means all children are taught in every lesson, rather than leaving some to their own devices.

@_MissieBee @trialnerrorkt @teacher_mr_r @one_to_read @TeachRepeat Absolutely. My class don't ever sit in ability groups - including in reading lessons. We all study the same text. Those who need extra support are targeted by TAs. Sometimes they will have pre-read the chapter with the TA so they get to hear it twice.

@one_to_read @trialnerrorkt @teacher_mr_r @TeachRepeat I'll also add that we have Reading For Pleasure time timetabled. During this time I listen to readers 1:1. We also have a weekly book talk lesson where we discuss books in depth as a class/small groups. So I get to talk to children about our class texts & ones they read alone.
@trialnerrorkt @teacher_mr_r @one_to_read @TeachRepeat Not with Y6, no.

@trialnerrorkt @DynamicDeps @teacher_mr_r @one_to_read @TeachRepeat @EducEndowFoundn @Suchmo83 Another argument for whole class is that reading is actually taught every day to all learners. In small groups, unless adults are supporting each one those children are not being taught.
@trialnerrorkt @teacher_mr_r @one_to_read @TeachRepeat I should also point out that when I say 'group', I don't mean ability groups. Mine don't sit in ability groups in any lesson, including reading.

@trialnerrorkt @teacher_mr_r @one_to_read @TeachRepeat 2/2 Then children read independently at their own pace. Teacher circulates and 'dips in' asking children to read to her from wherever they are. The purpose at this point is only fluency checking. TAs do the same. Then for the lesson content teachers may focus on one group.

@trialnerrorkt @teacher_mr_r @one_to_read @TeachRepeat 1/2 We don't do round robin where the whole class sot with the text and wait for their turn. Too much opportunity to coast, or not read at all & children don't hear the expert in the room enough. Instead, teachers always start the text first to model fluency...

@trialnerrorkt @teacher_mr_r @one_to_read @TeachRepeat 2/2 Now children read every day & teachers can hear more readers. Lessons are more purposeful. Teachers can still focus on a group a day for assessment pruposes, but doing a whole class approach means more children benefit from her guidance in more lessons.

@trialnerrorkt @teacher_mr_r @one_to_read @TeachRepeat 1/2 For me it was based on nothing but the fact that children weren't reading enough. Doing a carousel & teachers only listening to a group a day meant the others were coasting or off task. Fluency wasn't great & activities in some classes lacked purpose...
